author: RLE

review: The Amazon Fire TV somehow serves up a version of Amazon Prime that is inferior to its Roku counterpart. Regardless of if videos are available for streaming on Amazon Prime or not, the Amazon Fire TV tries to sell the videos to you. Videos on Prime and available in the Marketplace are integrated, which is great for people with more dollars than sense, but proves to be more of an inconvenience than anything else. Moreover, if you choose to turn on parental controls, even streaming videos will ask for the passcode. Without this inconvenience, though, nothing stands in the way of you and errant purchases.If you're willing to sideload apk files, the Fire TV makes a very capable emulation hub for fans of classic gaming. It's even a fairly decent game system with things like Terraria, Minecraft and Always Sometimes Monsters available for purchase, so long as you can stomach the stupidity of Amazon Coins when every other gaming company has just went the way of the dollar. Of course, it's hard to justify this over the Ouya or even a used Xbox 360 for the same price.In the end, the Amazon Fire TV is a Swiss Army Knife. It's capable of doing very many things, and there are people who are going to like the utility if they're already in the Amazon ecosystem. For everyone else, though, it's merely less than the sum of its parts.
